p.meta: We are incredibly appreciative of our staffs hard work and commitment to our students and families during these unsettling times as we, our region, state,and the world work through challenges brought by the new COVID-19 coronavirus. Additionally, we are thankful for the feedback you are providingas we endeavor to keep you and our students safe and informed through this ever-evolving situation.

div.p: We continue to partner with Public Health Seattle & King County to make decisions based on the safety, health, and well-being of all our students and staff. We are deeply appreciative of our staff and their efforts to support our students every day, and we appreciate your continued patience and flexibility during this unprecedented time.

li.a: Public Health Seattle & King County do not recommend closing schools
How are we working to keep staff safe and healthy?
I am exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19, but I am not in a high-risk population, and my doctor told me to stay home. What should I do?
I am in a high-risk category. What should I do?
Do I qualify for Washington States Paid Family Medical Leave related to COVID-19?
Should schools take any additional precautions?
Will remote learning be available district-wide for students?
Why aren't we closing all schools?
Will days have to be made up if schools close?
What if my school closes? What do I do?

h2.a: Public Health Seattle & King County do not recommend closing schools

div.p: Public Health Seattle & King County and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) do not recommend closing schools. The health organizations weighed recommendations for schools very carefully. Here are some of the reasonsthey recommendschools remain open:

ul.li: The available data about COVID-19 cases has shown children and youth have not been high risk groups for serious illness from this virus. COVID-19 infection in children tends to be more like a common cold or a mild fever.
Public Health Seattle & King County knowsschools are doing the important work of educating our children. They dont want to disrupt that unless there areconfirmedcoronavirus exposure risks.

Public Health Seattle & King County alsorecognizesschool closures have other impacts on working parents. School closures can be disruptive and costly for families, and they consider both the potential benefits and negative consequences of closures when they make recommendations.

div.p: If there is a confirmed case of COVID-19, Public Health will work with us to determine the best measures including potential school closure. As much as possible, children should be allowed to carry on with their education.

h2.a: How are we working to keep staff safe and healthy?

div.p: State and local public health officials announced new recommendations aimed at reducing risk of exposure to COVID-19.Included in the recommendations was information specific to people at higher risk of severe illness. Public Health is recommending, but not requiring, that people at higher risk of severe illness should stay home and away from large groups of people as much as possible, including public places with lots of people and large gatherings where there will be close contact with others.People at higher risk were identified as:

ul.li: people 60 and older
people with underlying health conditions including heart disease, lung disease or diabetes
people who have weakened immune systems
people who are pregnant

div.p: As always, staff who are ill should not report for work. Staff who become ill at work should immediately notify their supervisor and return home.

Employees who have concerns regarding their risk related to COVID-19 should consult with their health care provider regarding attendance at work. Human Resources will work with individual employees on the specifics of their personal situation.Should an employee receive a recommendation to remain away from work, they are to contact Laurie Taylor at laurie.taylor@rentonschools.us.
As this is an evolving situation, employees are encouraged to refer to information posted on the Public Health website, www.kingcounty.gov/COVID.

h2.a: I am exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19, but I am not in a high-risk population, and my doctor told me to stay home. What should I do?

div.p: If you are sick and/orexhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 (fever, cough, shortness of breath), you should immediately see your healthcare provider and stay home. Employees requiring substitutes should also enter the substitute request in the Frontline Absence Management system. This is treated just as any other circumstances when an employee is sick.

h2.a: I am in a high-risk category. What should I do?

div.p: Public Health has defined high-risk categories for COVID-19 as60 years or older, pregnant, weakened/compromised immune system, underlying health conditions such as heart disease, lung disease or diabetes.
As always, staff who are ill should not report for work. Staff who become ill at work should immediately notify their supervisor and return home.

Employees who have concerns regarding their risk related to COVID-19 should consult with their health care provider regarding attendance at work. Human Resources will work with individual employees on the specifics of their personal situation.Should an employee receive a recommendation to remain away from work, they are to contact Laurie Taylor at laurie.taylor@rentonschools.us.

h2.a: Do I qualify for Washington States Paid Family Medical Leave related to COVID-19?

div.p: As with any illness, to be eligible for paid medical leave, a healthcare provider must certify that you are unable to work due to a serious health condition. If your healthcare provider certifies your illness meets the definition of serious health condition and you have the qualifying hours, you can use Paid Family and Medical Leave for COVID-19 cases.

h2.a: Should schools take any additional precautions?

div.p: Public Health Seattle & King County says that at this time, schools do not need to take any special precautions beyond what is normally recommended to prevent the spread of respiratory viruses. Ourschool custodial staff follow standard procedures for cleaning, and wereinforce the need for students and staff to stay home when sick, wash hands frequently, avoid touching ones face, and take other preventative steps outlined by the health department.
WashingtonState Department of Health provides this helpful information on school cleaning practices: Guidance for Healthy Classroomsand Classroom Cleaning Tips for Teachers.
It's important piece of information is understanding the difference between Cleaning, Sanitizing, and Disinfecting; The Washington State Department of Health explains the difference as follows:

ul.li: CLEANING removes dirt and most germs. Use soap and water. Choose green cleaners such as Green Seal or EPAs Safer Choice. School and classroom cleaning can be done by students and staff.

SANITIZING reduces germs to safe levels, for example in food service environments. Food code regulations have specific requirements for sanitizers in the cafeteria and kitchen.Sanitizing should only be done by custodial and kitchen staff with proper personal protective equipment.

DISINFECTING kills most germs, depending on the type of chemical, and only when used as directed on the label.Disinfecting should only be done by custodial staff with proper personal protective equipment.
In schools, custodial staff use disinfectants and sanitizers regularly only in high-risk areas nurses office, bathrooms, cafeterias, kitchens, drinking fountains, sink and door handles, and athletic facilities; preferably, when students are not present. Overuse does not provide any additional protection and can expose students and staff to harmful chemicals.

div.p: Please keep in mind, students should never use disinfectants. Disinfectant wipes shouldn't be used to clean hands. This includes Clorox (bleach) wipes. If students are helping to clean:

ul.li: They should only use soap and water.
Fragrance-free baby wipes could be used for quick cleaning.
Most store-bought cleaning products are not safe for children to use.

div.p: Renton School District uses these FDA-approved products to clean, sanitize and disinfect: disinfecting and sanitizing are done by only by custodial staff with appropriate personal protective equipment.

ul.li:
DISINFECTING - Diversey - Oxivir
Used by the custodial staff to disinfect hard surfaces and touchpoints

SANITIZING - Diversey - Virex II 256
Used daily by custodial staff to disinfect in restrooms

CLEANING - Diversey - Stride
Neutral Cleaneravailable for staff to use in classrooms. Spray bottles with labels and cleaner are available at schools Staff should contact their custodian if they would like to have this cleaner for their workspace.
Unscented Baby Wipes - An initial supply of unscented baby wipes for use in classrooms and workspaces and are distributed to building custodians.

h2.a: Will remote learning be available district-wide for students?

div.p: At this time, we will not be moving to a remote learning model. We will support students who are out of school for extended absences due to a documented illness or quarantine/isolation, and teachers will work with students and families regarding coursework. We currently leverage many digital tools to support in-class learning, however replacing in-person classroom learning with remote learning for all students in the district presents several challenges. Schools serve students and families in capacities beyond instruction, including nutrition services, counseling services, etc., and closing on short notice presents many regulatory, logistical, and equity challenges.

h2.a: Why aren't we closing all schools?

div.p: Public Health Seattle & King County and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) do not recommend closingschools.The health organizations weighed recommendations for schools very carefully. Here are some of the reasonsthey recommendschools remain open:

ul.li: The available data about COVID-19 cases has shown children and youth have not been high risk groups for serious illness from this virus. COVID-19 infection in children tends to be more like a common cold or a mild fever.
Public Health Seattle & King County knowsschools are doing the important work of educating our children. They dont want to disrupt that unless there areconfirmedcoronavirus exposure risks.

Public Health Seattle & King County alsorecognizesschool closures have other impacts on working parents. School closures can be disruptive and costly for families, and they consider both the potential benefits and negative consequences of closures when they make recommendations.

div.p: If there is a confirmed case of COVID-19, Public Health will work with us to determine the best measures including potential school closure. As much as possible, children should be allowed to carry on with their education.

p.meta: While prioritizing the health and safety of our students and staff, we also feel the responsibility to continue services to our students and community as long as Public Health says it is safe. At the same time, we want to ensure that staff who need to stay home as a result of high risk or illness are supported in taking that time off. As we continue to implement strategies to minimize risk of transmission, and to maximize the number of substitutes available to step in to support schools, we have cancelled all events, workshops, etc. that require a substitute teacher.

The health of our staff is important to us. Employees who have concerns regarding their risk related to COVID-19 should consult with their healthcare provider regarding attendance at work. Human Resources will work with individual employees on the specifics of their personal situation. Should an employee receive a recommendation to remain away from work, please contact Laurie Taylor, Assistant Superintendent of Human Resources, at laurie.taylor@rentonschools.us.

h2.a: Will days have to be made up if schools close?

div.p: The decision on whether makeup days will be held will be determined at a future date. The District will work with OSPI and labor partners before this decision is made.

h2.a: What if my school closes? What do I do?

div.p: Public Health's current directive to keep schools open. However, if aschool is closed, staff will be directed on what actions to take.
